captions.text:
The Universe. How big is it? Does it have
a center? Does it have an edge? Is it getting
bigger, and if so, why?

Well, we know that there are two different
meanings for "universe" - first, the "observable

universe" is everything that we've been able
to see, or observe, thus far. And second,

"The Universe" (or "the whole universe") means
everything that exists or has existed, or
will exist.

More specifically, the observable universe
is the region of space visible to us from

earth. And since The Universe is only about
13.8 billion years old and light takes time

to travel through space, then regardless of
what direction we look, we see light that's

been traveling (at most) 13.8 billion years.
So it's logical to think that the observable

universe must then be 2*13.77 = 27.5 billion
light years across - but it's not. That's

because over time, space has been expanding,
so the distant objects that gave off that

light 13.8 billion years ago have since moved
even farther away from us. Today, those distant

objects are a bit more than 46 billion light
years away. Multiply times two and you get

93 billion light years: the diameter of the
observable universe.

To give you a sense of scale, the size of
the earth within the observable universe is

roughly equivalent to the size of a virus
within the solar system - although that doesn't

help much because we can't really appreciate
the incomprehensible smallness of a virus

nor the bewildering bigness of the solar system,
either.

So let's just say that the observable universe
is stupendously big. But The Whole Universe,

as far as we can tell, is a lot bigger - space
is most likely infinite! Or at least it doesn't

have an edge, though the difference between
those is another story unto itself.

Now, what about the center of the universe?
Well the observable universe has a center

- Us! We're at the center of the observable
universe because the observable universe is

just the region of space visible from earth,
and kind of like how the view from a very

tall tower is a circle centered on the tower,
the piece of space we can see from here is

naturally centered here. In fact, if you want
to be more precise, EACH ONE OF US is the
center of our OWN observable universe.

But that doesn't mean we're at the center
of The Whole Universe, just like the tower

isn't the center of the world - it's the center
of the piece of the world that it can see

- up to the horizon. But just because you
can't see beyond the horizon doesn't mean
there's nothing there.

And so it is with the observable universe.
Looking up at the sky, we see light light

that's at most 13.8 billion years old and
coming from stuff that's now 46 billion light

years away. Anything farther is "beyond the
horizon". But each second, we see new, even

older light coming from slightly farther away
(one light-second farther, to be precise),

and so our view of the cosmos is literally
getting bigger all the time - all we have

to do is wait and watch as the universe ages
and light from more distant places has the
time to get to us.

So here we are, sitting at the center of our
observable piece of the Whole Universe.

How big is the universe? Well, the observable
universe is currently 93 billion light years

across. The Whole Universe is probably infinite.
Does the universe have an edge? The observable

does (it's 46 billion light years away in
any direction), and The Whole Universe has

a temporal edge (or what we call a beginning)
but almost certainly not a spatial one.

Does the universe have a center? Again, the
observable universe does: YOU! The Universe

as a whole? Almost certainly not.
And is the universe getting bigger? Yes - space

is expanding, which makes both the observable
universe and the whole universe bigger - plus,

over time, we see older and older light coming
from farther and farther away, so our observable
universe gets bigger that way, too.

And that, in a nutshell, is our view from
the tower. You are the center of the universe.

And so am I. And so is everyone else. And
so is no one.

We are in a reversed black hole. Instead of things getting sucked into a

It a "Reversed Black Hole Theory". We could possibly be an infinite black 
hole from another infinite universe. The other end of that infinate black 
hole is a big bang giving birth to a new infinite universe . I call that 
the "Multiverse" ripping fabrics through space and time creating a new 
limitless universe. This process could also go on an infinite number of 
times so it's virtually limitless. ﻿

comments.text:
This guy is contradicting himself so much it's almost humorous. Almost. He 
is missing the analogy of the ''observable universe' While we can see a 
vast amount of space going back 13.8 billion years - the Universe will 
always continue to ''go on'' if we wait to see new additions to it. 
Considering the universe is Constantly expanding. This doesn't mean that 
there is more being created - just that there is more separation between 
objects - such as galaxies. We know these things by measuring the energy in 
the Universe and seeing it's expansion. You could roll everything up back 
into a ball from a central point and this is something that we can see. 
Everything is expanding from a central location, which means at one point 
in time the universe was much smaller while still retaining the same amount 
of mass and energy. Thus we must ask the question because the Law of 
thermodynamics and entropy do not lie, what caused the Universe's creation? 
Was it 'nothingness'? Of course not, it had to be something that was not 
restricted to time, space, matter, or energy ( i.e. God). Thus something 
Supernatural had to create the natural, something beyond our Universe had 
to create the Universe. The best, and in my opinion only, explanation for 
this is God. The Universe is not INFINITE, because it is not ETERNAL. If 
the Universe is not Eternal, it can not be infinite, and since the Universe 
is only so old - then it can only be so big by the rate of it's expansion. 
Some people here need to read some books besides watching a single Youtube 
video and believing they know it all. I recommend books by such men as: 
Frank Turek, Norman Geisler, or William Lane Craig.﻿

comments.author: JD Studios

comments.text:
Hm, unfortunately that description does not agree with what we can observe 
about the universe.

While it has indeed 3 spacial dimensions, we do not observe standing waves 
in it as a whole, nor can we find any borders that would be neccessary to 
create such waves. There is also no "universal equator", as we find the 
universe to be homogeneous and isotropic at a scale above about 300 mio 
lightyears, making the chioce of an "equator" completely arbitrary (in 
contrast to e.g. earth, where the equator has physical meaning). We also 
have not found any spacial borders to the universe as of now and there is 
no indication that such borders could even exist. As such, the notion of 
"halfway from the top and halfway from the bottom" is nonsensical. There is 
also no indication that we are at any special point in the universe and 
even more: the galaxies (and matter) is distributed almost like a sponge in 
the universe.

I would recommend reading up on the observations about the cosmos in the 
last 200 years before making such claims in the future ... you know, just 
so you don't look like an idiot to people who actually know a little bit 
about the cosmos ;)

comments.text:
Yeah... I'm religious. People ask where God is from and whatever not. But 
even if you don't believe in a God. 

How could you possibly understand the creator of something. If you can't 
even understand the created. Well I also will never understand how either 
the universe is infinite, or finite and thus with an edge and expanding. 
Expanding into what??

''Expanding into what'', that's all you guys think. We're humans, humans 
think their own way and will never understand things like a God or science. 
You could compare us to a system like Windows or OS X. When you put a 
program not designed in it, it just won't get to work. Those matters are 
too big for our brains. We think too much in our senses as those senses are 
all we have. But what about our heart? For who wants to see there's light. 
Well why didn't God give us more powerful brains then? No need, there are 
already people pure in their heart, being able to see with their heart. For 
if you ask I only belief what I see then a blind man would never believe. 

Imagination cannot reach Him, so as to assign Him quantity. 
Understanding cannot think of Him, so as to give Him shape. 
Senses do not perceive Him, so as to feel Him. 
Hands cannot touch Him, so as to rub against him. 
He does not change into any condition.
He does not pass from one state to another.
Nights and days do not turn him old.
Light and darkness do not alter Him.
It cannot be said that He has a limit or extremity, or end or termination. 
Nor do things control Him so as to raise Him or lower Him.
Not does anything carry Him, so as to bend Him or keep Him erect. 
He is not inside things nor outside them. 
He conveys news, but not with the tongue or voice. 
He listens, but not with the holes of the ears or the organs of hearing. 
He says, but does not utter words. 
He remembers, but does not memorize.
He determines, but not by exercising His mind. 
He loves and approves without any sentimentality (of heart).
He hates and feels angry without any painstaking. 
When He intends to create someone He says ''Be'' and there he is,
but not through a voice that strikes the ears is that called heard. 
His speech is an act of His creation
The foremost in religion is the acknowledgement of Him,
the perfection of acknowledging Him is to testify Him, 
the perfection of testifying him is to believe in His oneness, 
the perfection of believing in His Oneness is to regard him pure,
and the perfection of His purity is to deny Him attributes, 
because every attribute is a proof that it is different from that to which 
it is attributed. 
And everything to which something is attributed is different from the 
attribute.
Thus whoever attaches attributes to God recognizes His like,
and who recognizes His like regards Him two;
and who regards Him two recognizes parts for Him;
and who recognizes parts for Him mistook Him;
and who mistook him pointed at Him;
and who pointed at Him admitted limitations for Him;
and who admitted limitations for Him numbered Him. 
Whoever said ''in what is He?'' held that He is contained;
and whoever said ''on what is He held?'' He is not on something else. 
He is a Being but not through the phenomenon of coming into being. 
He exists but not from non-existence.
He is with everything but not in a physical nearness. 
He is different from everything but not in physical separation. 
He acts but without connotation of movements and instruments.
He sees even when there is none to be looked at from among His creation.
He is only One, such that there is none with whom He may keep company,
or whom He may miss in his absence. 

''We will show them our signs in the universe, and their own selves until 
it becomes manifest to them that this is the truth.''﻿

comments.author: AlexDaBeast

comments.text:
We are told there are billions of galaxies in our observable universe. What 
if there are not as many as we think we see?
We know light bends around a gravity source in curved space-time. And light 
photons travel out in all directions from a source. We see a relatively 
close galaxy directly and can measure its speed, size, distance, and age. 
But what if that galaxies light that moves out in other directions gets 
bent and angled back towards us? Wouldn't we then see a second similar 
galaxy type in a different point in space that would appear to be older and 
more distant, (since the light took a longer route), and moving away at a 
faster rate (since each angle point is expanding and moving away from each 
other)? 
Couldn't this happen multiple times? So that we can be seeing the same 
close galaxy, angled back to us multiple times from different directions at 
different points in it's historical evolution? Couldn't we also be seeing 
our own Milky Way Galaxy multiple times as it appeared in the past? ﻿

comments.author: Keir Rowlands

comments.text:
+xRockycherrYx "a theory can't ever be proven."

Scientific theories don't claim to prove anything 100%, smartass. But its 
pretty easy to tell if something is true *beyond all reasonable doubt*. And 
general relativity is true beyond all reasonable doubt, with massive 
amounts of evidence for it. Anyone with the slightest amount of education 
in science will know this.

"you lack the ability to think outside the box."

So spouting out nonsensical, fantastical, and more importantly baseless 
statements like "our observable universe may be an illusion" is suddenly 
justified? You make me laugh.
comments.author: Radioactive Banana

comments.text:
+soup that is too hot
Much of what you just said is wrong. For example, a theory can't ever be 
proven... only disproved. So it's pretty clear that you are the one who 
doesn't understand much about science. But, more importantly, you lack the 
ability to think outside the box. This conversation clearly doesn't amount 
to anything, so...have a nice life...
comments.author: xRockycherrYx

comments.text:
+xRockycherrYx "General relativity is only a theory"

Now I know you're a troll who doesn't even understand anything about 
science.

A scientific theory is not a guess or hypothetical possibility. It's a 
model that explains a body of facts and phenomena. In this case, it 
explains relativity in relation to gravity. Its been pretty conclusively 
proven already as well, and in terms of mathematically describing certain 
things it turned out to be extremely accurate.

Believe it or not, science can do wondrous things despite how small we are 
in the vastness of the cosmos.

We know the universe is 13.8 billion years old because the farthest things 
we can see are 13.8 billion ly away. If the universe was older, the 
observable universe would be larger, because more light would have reached 
us by now. There. Now I've had to explain it to both of you.
comments.author: Radioactive Banana

comments.text:
+soup that is too hot General relativity is only a theory, so it can't 
confirm anything...it can only support. And yes, if you're saying that we 
humans can with our primitive means actually tell how old and big the whole 
existing universe is, then you might as well say we are capable of 
observing everything (at least theoretically). Chances are 50/50 that 
nothing we ever observed actually tells us anything relevant about the 
whole universe. Because our observable universe might be just an illusion.
comments.author: xRockycherrYx

comments.text:
+xRockycherrYx Mate (or girl), what are you on about? Do you not understand 
what I'm saying? I'm saying our universe is 13.8 billion years old, because 
the farthest things we can see are 13.8 billion ly away. General relativity 
also confirms that the universe is 13.8 billion years old. If the universe 
was any older or younger, we'd be able to tell because the observable 
universe would be larger or smaller depending on its age. It seems to me 
that everyone here has muddled up the definition of the observable 
universe...

When did I say that humans are capable of observing everything that exists?
comments.author: Radioactive Banana

comments.text:
+soup that is too hot
So you seriously think we humans are capable of observing everything that 
exists? With the primitive technical means we developed up until today? Or 
do you just not understand what everyone here means when they are talking 
about the "observable universe" and, on the other hand,  the "whole 
universe"? Our "observable universe" is everything we are theoretically 
able to observe by now. And probably everything we will ever be able to 
observe. We are only primitive creatures with very limited senses. Of 
course, there is always the possibility that our universe only consists of 
our "observable universe". But then what lies beyond it... Nothing? The 
point is: we will never be able to know anything for sure. We just can't 
ever know if we can rely on anything we observe!
comments.author: xRockycherrYx

comments.text:

picture.

comments.author: Keir Rowlands

comments.text:
+Keir Rowlands Thats not what you said in your original comment. Are you 
referring to the multiverse theory? If so, the theory holds that all these 
universes are separate. There is no "real universe" that encompasses 
everything. OUR universe (and not just the observable part) is 13.8 billion 
years old starting from the Big Bang. This "real universe" you are talking 
about, whatever that is, would presumably have always existed. 

Lol and you don't need to be a scientist to know this stuff. A little bit 
of curiosity is all it takes.
comments.author: Radioactive Banana

comments.text:
+soup that is too hot lol well you seem to think you have all the answers, 
are you an astrophysicist?, dude you're not reading what im saying, yes OUR 
universe is 13.8 billion years old FROM the Big Bang because the farthest 
point we can see in all directions is 13.8 light years, I GET IT you swine 
chill out, I'm talking about a bigger picture, the big bang could be one of 
several big bangs that are spread apart thus making the "real universe" 
(its all speculation because like i said we dont know this yet) much older 
(unless our big bang was the first in existence or the only one in

comments.author: Keir Rowlands

comments.text:
+Keir Rowlands How much more of a moron can you be? I literally JUST 
explained the age calculation process to you and you still don't get it. It 
wouldn't matter at all if there is an object farther off who's life hasn't 
reached us! If there was a star who's light didn't reach us it would mean 
the universe hasn't been around long enough to reach us. Thus, because the 
farthest things we see are 13.8 billion light years away the universe must 
be 13.8 billion years old. If the universe was say, more than 13.8 billion 
years old, we would see objects that are farther than 13.8 light years 
away. *But we don't*, so the universe cannot be older than 13.8 billion 
years old. The fact that there are stars that we can't see is PROOF that 
the universe has a finite age but old age. Until you provide verifiable 
evidence that directly contradicts this line of evidence, it is pointless 
to ask 'what if'. The reason I call you a moron is because I keep 
explaining this to you and you still don't seem to understand. You don't 
even need me to explain it to you, as you could always just do some 
research on the web on your own. If you consider this an 'intellectual' 
conversation, you should probably gather this prior knowledge beforehand.
comments.author: Radioactive Banana

comments.text:
+soup that is too hot Lol you kind of just fuelled my argument a bit, how 
do you know there's not an object farther off in the distance who's light 
hasn't reached us yet? with today's technology your right it is an 
absolutely great method and is quite accurate. but it doesn't mean it is 
definite, your right tho it is likely that is not the case because its 13.8 
in all directions but again its the universe, too much mystery shrouds it 
to be fully concluding. And i'd love to see you say your stupidity is 
overwhelming to me or someone's face, keyboard warriors these days... if 
you're a scrawny little kid who gets bullied that ain't my fault but lets 
keep this conversation intellectual there bud.
comments.author: Keir Rowlands

comments.text:
+Keir Rowlands You still don't seem to understand the method used to find 
the age of the universe. Its calculated by seeing how far away the most 
distance objects are. If they are 13.8 billion light years away and we are 
able to see them, it must mean the universe is 13.8 billion years old 
because if it was older we'd be able to see farther objects.

When the guy in the video said infinite, he's referring to how it works 
like a bubble and the surface of that bubble is the universe. There is no 
edge, so it is in a sense "infinite." I don't know what you mean by not 
being able to calculate something because we can't see the light. As I said 
before, the fact that we can't see all the light PROVES that the universe 
must be 13.8 billion years. If it was any older, that light would have 
travelled to us by now and we'd be able to see it, but we don't. Its not 
unquantifiable. The age we have certainly has a degree of uncertainty, and 
so it could be off by 1 or 0.5 billion years. However, it is a reasonably 
accurate estimate.
comments.author: Radioactive Banana

comments.text:
+soup that is too hot Technically it doesn't have to do with time your 
right, but the point of it was that you don't know forsure whats entirely 
out there, yes light has travelled 13.8 billion light years so they can 
formulate how long that is, the guy in the video is saying the universe is 
13.8 billion light years in all directions from the earth that would make 
it enclosed and bordered into a circle in the video which it does its the 
 "observable universe" cause thats what we can physically see, time/ 
distance/ speed all directly effect each other. so from which we stand on 
earth using that formula that was our answer, however the entire universe 
like this guy said is most likely infinite, therefore meaning that we can't 
calculate it because there is no light to see! and your different age 
metaphor doesn't work because of the method used to calculate the 
observable universe, and the multiverse reference was like we could jus be 
another dot in a whole other universe itself that was around before ours 
got created, its too unquantifiable as of right now.

billion years old why would the rest of the universe have a different age? 
Its like saying your nose is older than your mouth. It makes no sense.

comments.author: WhiteNavayo

comments.text:
+WhiteNavayo 2. Infinity is not a number at all. It's just a concept. 
That's why it gets tricky when you treat it as a number. 3. That's quite 
contradictory. I'm sure you don't believe in magicians being capable to 
summon a rabbit from a hat. As you said what we know comes from the 
interaction between our minds and reality. So I think it's quite extreme to 
say that we must believe what we can see/hear/feel because your mind could 
just as well be lying to you. Well do you know about subliminal messages? 
They do work. You do not feel that you got the message, your mind doesn't 
find it necessary to make you notice it, but it does affect you. A higher 
force of nature could just as well be doing the same thing.
comments.author: Daniel Barihuta

comments.text:
+Daniel Barihuta 2. Yes, it eaquals one, if its infinite, but, since 
infinity is not a precice number, its not quite one, but I agree with you 
on that.
3. Everything we know is how our minds interpret signals coming from, say, 
eyes or noses, thus we must believe what we can see/hear/feel. (thats why I 
dont believe in a higher force of nature, since I have absolutely no proof 
of it) 

PS. I'm not saying what I wrote is completely correct, theory is almost 
always quite far from reality, but, as i said before, we have to make 
something out of what our tiny human minds can get a grasp on.
comments.author: WhiteNavayo

comments.text:
+WhiteNavayo I see what you're trying to do.
The first one is only true in the case of the universe being infinite. The 
second one is a geometric sequence and the answer is absolutely not zero 
it's 1. Or you can see it as the limit to be one. It's actually easy to 
see.If you have One square of 1cm and you divide it continuously following 
that series you will see that it works. It has already been proven. A quick 
little search on the net will prove you that. The third is true but 
consider also this. You can match every single number from a "bigger" 
infinite series to another number from a "smaller". Thus making those two 
series equall. So they are different AND equall at the same time. Another 
paradox? You said it it's in theory. Theory can be very different from 
reality. And you also said 'in our minds'. Doesn't mean it is true in 
reality.
comments.author: Daniel Barihuta

comments.text:
+Daniel Barihuta How many stars can we see? Theoretically infinite.
How much is 1/2 + 1/4 + 1/8 + 1/16 ... ? THEORETICALLY infinite. AND some 
infinities are bigger than others. They do exist, like everything else we 
believe is true, inside our minds. (e.g. try describing the colour green to 
a born blind person )
